0.27.text:
SARAH ANNESE: Thank you
everybody for having us.

2.27.text:
This is one of the coolest
things we've ever done.

5.55.text:
As Thomas, said
I'm Sarah Annese.

8.71.text:
We are married, not brother and
sister-- common misconception.

14.88.text:
So we wrote "Beer
Lover's New York."

17.53.text: We're super excited to be here.

18.91.text:
Thank you guys for
having us, and we're

21.02.text:
excited to try some
home brews later.

27.67.text:
Last May we were up
in Glens Falls, which

32.65.text:
is kind of like northern
New York in the Adirondacks.

36.76.text:
And we were visiting this
little brewery called Davidson

39.48.text:
Brothers, and it was, you
know, like a little brew pub.

42.49.text:
And we're talking to the
founder, Rick Davidson,

45.54.text:
and there's a lull
in conversation

47.56.text:
and he kind of turns to me and
goes, what size are your feet?

51.34.text:
So next thing I know I'm inside
the brewing kettle-- cleaning

61.00.text:
So then like a month
later, we find ourselves

64.13.text:
100 feet up in the air
in a cherry picker,

66.58.text:
in the middle of
the finger lakes

67.95.text:
looking over at
what is soon going

70.71.text:
to be-- which you
could see here--

72.84.text:
a brewery called
Miles Craft Ales.

77.75.text:
This whole experience
of writing this book

79.70.text:
has had so many times where
we've kind of just looked

83.32.text:
at each other and been like,
holy crap-- are we really here?

87.79.text:
So those are just two examples
of that kind of thing.

92.68.text:
New York State has an
incredibly rich beer history.

96.42.text:
At one time, the state produced
90% of the country's hops.

102.19.text:
And we have these two really
historical breweries--

108.37.text:
Matt Brewing, which
was founded in 1888,

112.90.text:
is still owned by
the Matt family.

115.27.text:
And made the first beer served
after prohibition legally--

124.14.text:
And then we also have Genesee,
which was founded in 1878.

127.96.text:
And even though it's
not craft anymore,

129.84.text:
it's still part of New
York state beer history.

133.32.text:
Fast forward to today--
since we finished

138.70.text:
writing the book,
which was August 5th,

142.63.text:
30 breweries have
opened up in New York.

145.21.text:
So it's definitely a
really exciting time

147.77.text:
to be involved in beer
in New York state.

151.71.text:
The laws are changing to
support this industry,

159.81.text:
How we got this
book-- as Thomas said,

166.92.text:
It started as a
little blog in 2009,

169.81.text:
and we redeveloped it
into website in 2012.

173.77.text:
And then in April of 2013 we
just got an email, randomly,

179.81.text:
from an editor at Globe
Pequot Press asking us

182.63.text: if we could write this book.

184.63.text:
And we were just kind of
like, what, yes, of course.

188.43.text:
So we are part of a
beer lover series.

193.78.text:
There's beer lover's
Colorado, beer lover's Oregon,

196.34.text:
beer lover's mid-Atlantic--
books about regional and state

205.82.text:
So we are the New
York one, and our book

211.96.text:
It covers the best-- not
all-- but the best breweries,

216.16.text:
brew pubs, and bars
across the whole state.

222.54.text:
There is New York City,
Long Island, Hudson Valley,

225.61.text:
capital region, northern New
York and the Adirondacks,

229.17.text:
central New York and the Finger
Lakes, and Western New York.

232.96.text:
So today we're going
to talk a little bit

234.67.text:
about regional trends
across the state

238.19.text:
and also highlight some
interesting and exciting

243.98.text:
GIANCARLO ANNESE: One of
the most challenging parts

246.57.text:
about it was the four
months that we had

249.17.text: and the size of the state.

251.80.text:
To do the research we
traveled over 4,000 miles

256.64.text:
from Buffalo, Lake
Placid, Green Port.

259.88.text:
So we were all over, and
we only had four months

262.15.text:
to do this while holding

266.69.text:
So it was a lot
of long weekends,

269.64.text: a lot of time in the car.

We used trains, planes,

We had our adventures
on Amtrak and such.

282.86.text:
I mean, we were
all over the place.

And some of the trips were
kind of natural trips,

288.82.text:
and we knew right
from when we started

that they would be dedicated
trips-- like the Adirondacks

298.17.text:
That's one of the first

we sat down and
looked at the state--

304.91.text:
where the breweries
were, what kind of trips

we were going to need

309.24.text: we could jam into these trips.

312.58.text:
Because with 135 breweries,
plus bars and home

316.70.text:
brew shops and festivals
that we also covered,

321.20.text:
it was a lot to fit
into four months.

324.08.text:
We had trips to
Rochester, Buffalo, self

327.61.text:
explanatory trips, and around
the New York City area, which

330.25.text:
thankfully we already knew
pretty well from covering

But probably the biggest

How many of you have been
around the Finger Lakes?

346.15.text:
Do you guys know the

351.44.text:
There's a lot of small roads
connecting these breweries--

354.83.text:
not really major
highways connecting them.

357.77.text:
You have 90 that
runs along the north,

361.69.text:
and you have Route 17
that runs along the south.

But in the middle
there are a lot

368.23.text:
of roads that run
north-south but not much

372.64.text:
So it was tough to get
to all these breweries,

375.97.text:
try to meet with the
brewers, and taste the beer.

381.03.text:
So we had to do a bunch
of different trips

383.57.text:
to the Finger Lakes
and central New York.

387.68.text:
Thankfully, Sarah did
most of the driving,

391.92.text:
and I did most of the tasting--
which was pretty good for me.

397.35.text:
And some of the days we
were at a brewery at noon,

402.02.text:
and we would hit five

SARAH ANNESE: It's

that's not what

I think we visited

I'm sure most of you

466.61.text:
I think, some people
by actually going

468.41.text:

We got to really see what

475.58.text:
and how the regions

One of the regions that
surprised us the most

seem to care very
much about what's

498.55.text:

519.81.text:
People will get over
it and stop using

522.04.text:
hops so much, they'll get back

526.27.text:
and, you know,
they'll just get over.

529.98.text:
That was one of
those moments where

533.79.text:
I mean, it's kind of great
that these people just

536.41.text:
do what they do and
they don't care.

SARAH ANNESE: And I mean

540.85.text:
They just never brew

542.73.text:
and they just stick

There's something really

And then even this

Blue Line Brewing, in Saranac

So they benefited from

563.77.text:
But he's kind of the
experimental brewer

So it's not a American pale ale,
that by most other standards

590.35.text:
The hops are almost

that stuff-- compared to

it's kind of incredible

kind of, we thought,

that we had when

It's got a light body,

711.53.text:
But they use Ethiopian

718.09.text:
It smells exactly like

722.50.text:
that you might associate

And then you get this really

729.98.text:
and it's a little

736.29.text:

see there on the bottom left,

746.22.text:

750.25.text:
It's right across the street

753.63.text:
station, and they've got
one of the first coolships

759.37.text:
So they have cooled

767.01.text:
And they're brewing things
like simple sour, which

771.50.text:
is corn and wheat based
and also really sour, tart,

776.10.text:
refreshing-- great for

And they brew a beer
called Amazeballs, which

is like an IPA with all

788.07.text:
but without bitterness,

790.36.text: use much bittering hops at all.

792.57.text:
So they're really
trying to find new ways

795.06.text:
to do interesting things

And then they have little
guys like Sloop Brewing, which

803.71.text:
you may have heard

But they started
out in a garage,

811.26.text:
selling a peach berliner

So the Hudson Valley
for us really kind of

821.13.text:
showcased the wide variety

SARAH ANNESE: Really

831.74.text: And then in New York City.

New York City-- I'm

844.56.text:

So a place like Big Alice

You walk into the
brewery and it's

862.39.text:
just-- it's just

SARAH ANNESE: Can

They're moving to a

So they're really kind

Like Chris Cuzme,
which is actually

898.95.text:
at 508 Gastrobrewery--

It's a small, two

919.38.text:

These tiny little

932.30.text:

But we're also getting some of

946.05.text:
like Sam Richardson at Other

IPA's-- so the complete

New York City is seeing

kind of landscape of beer
